question.title: Will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Liz Cheney becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: Liz Cheney has been a vocal critic of former President Donald Trump and voted to impeach him. This has put her at odds with a significant portion of the Republican base that still supports Trump. 2. Recent political history: Cheney lost her leadership position in the House Republican Conference and was censured by the Wyoming Republican Party due to her stance against Trump. 3. 2022 Primary results: Cheney lost her primary race for Wyoming's at-large congressional district to a Trump-backed candidate, indicating a lack of support from Republican voters in her home state. 4. Current polling: Cheney is not currently a frontrunner in any national polls for the 2024 Republican nomination. Candidates like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and others are consistently polling much higher. 5. Fundraising and support: While Cheney has some support from anti-Trump Republicans and even some Democrats, she lacks the broad party support and fundraising network typically needed to secure a nomination. 6. Party dynamics: The Republican Party has largely aligned itself with Trump's vision and policies, which are at odds with Cheney's more traditional conservative approach. 7. Time until convention: While there is still time until the 2024 Republican National Convention, it would require a massive shift in party dynamics and voter preferences for Cheney to become a viable nominee. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that Liz Cheney will be selected as the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While unexpected events could potentially change the political landscape, based on the current information and trends, the probability of this occurring is very low.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbency advantage: Historically, sitting presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless faced with extraordinary circumstances. Biden has already indicated his intention to run for re-election. 2. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 at the start of a potential second term, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. This has raised concerns about his ability to serve effectively for another four years. 3. Current polling and approval ratings: Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, which could potentially influence his decision. However, approval ratings can fluctuate significantly over time. 4. Democratic Party support: Despite some concerns, the Democratic Party leadership has largely rallied behind Biden, and there is no clear alternative candidate with broad party support. 5. Political landscape: The Republican opposition and the potential for a rematch with Donald Trump may motivate Biden to run again to prevent a return of Trump or a Trump-like candidate to the White House. 6. Time frame: The question asks about an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in July or August). It's unlikely that a sitting president would wait until the last minute to make such a significant announcement. 7. Biden's public statements: As of now, Biden has consistently stated his intention to run for re-election, including filing paperwork with the Federal Election Commission to run in 2024. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he will not accept the nomination. The incumbency advantage, party support, and his own public statements strongly indicate his intention to run. While age and health concerns exist, they don't appear to be severe enough to force him out of the race at this point. The only scenario where this might occur is if there's a sudden, severe health issue or an unforeseen political scandal. However, the probability of such an event occurring and leading to this specific outcome before July 15, 2024, is quite low.

question.title: Will either Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election or Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, or (b) Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, stating that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

For Liz Cheney, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

For Joe Biden, to qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this part of the question will resolve as No.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving as YES, we need to consider both parts separately and then combine their likelihoods. 1. Liz Cheney being the Republican nominee for 2024: Liz Cheney has become a polarizing figure within the Republican Party due to her criticism of former President Trump and her role in the January 6th committee. She lost her House seat in Wyoming's primary election in 2022, indicating a lack of support from her own party's base. The Republican Party has largely aligned itself with Trump's policies and rhetoric, making it highly unlikely for Cheney to secure the nomination. The probability of this occurring is extremely low, perhaps less than 1%. 2. Joe Biden announcing he won't accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024: As of now (2023), Joe Biden has indicated his intention to run for re-election in 2024. However, there are several factors that could potentially change this: a) Biden's age: He would be 82 at the start of a second term, which raises concerns about his ability to serve effectively. b) Health issues: Any significant health problems could prompt him to step aside. c) Poor approval ratings: If his popularity continues to decline, he might decide it's better for the party to have a different candidate. d) Family considerations: Personal reasons could lead to a change in his plans. Despite these factors, it's still more likely that Biden will run for re-election. Presidents rarely choose not to seek a second term, and the Democratic Party doesn't have a clear alternative candidate with broad support. The probability of Biden announcing he won't accept the nomination before July 15, 2024, is higher than Cheney becoming the Republican nominee, but still relatively low - perhaps around 15-20%. Combining these probabilities, we need to consider the chance of either event occurring. Since they are independent events, we can use the formula P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B). Given that the probability of both events happening simultaneously is negligible, we can essentially add the probabilities. Therefore, the overall probability of this question resolving as YES is approximately 0.01 (Cheney) + 0.18 (Biden) = 0.19 or 19%.

question.title: Will the Prime Minister of France belong to a coalition other than New Popular Front or Together on July 30, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if the party of the Prime Minister of France is not New Popular Front or Together on July 30th, at 12:00 Central European Time, according to credible sources.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of April 2023, the Prime Minister of France is Elisabeth Borne, who belongs to the 'Together' coalition (Renaissance party, which is part of the 'Ensemble' or 'Together' coalition). 2. Time until resolution: The question resolves on July 30, 2024, which is more than a year away from the current date. This long timeframe increases uncertainty. 3. French political system: The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and can be changed at any time without requiring new elections. 4. Recent political events: France has seen significant political unrest and protests in 2023, which could potentially lead to changes in government. 5. Historical precedent: French politics has been relatively stable in recent years, with Prime Ministers typically serving for several years. 6. Upcoming elections: The next French legislative elections are scheduled for 2027, which is after the resolution date of this question. This reduces the likelihood of a major political shift due to elections. Given these factors, it seems more likely that the current coalition (Together) will remain in power until July 30, 2024. However, there are several reasons why this might not be the case: a) The current political unrest could lead to a reshuffling of the government. b) President Macron might decide to change the Prime Minister to address public dissatisfaction. c) Unforeseen political events or scandals could force a change in leadership. Considering all these factors, I believe it is unlikely that the Prime Minister will belong to a coalition other than New Popular Front or Together on July 30, 2024. However, given the long timeframe and potential for political changes, there is still a non-negligible chance of this occurring.

question.title: Will the ID political group hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the ID political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections. It will resolve as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the Identity and Democracy (ID) political group holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current composition: As of 2023, the ID group is not the largest in the European Parliament. It currently holds 62 out of 705 seats, making it the 5th largest group. 2. Recent trends: There has been a rise in right-wing populist and nationalist sentiments across Europe in recent years. This could potentially benefit the ID group, which includes parties with these ideologies. 3. Electoral systems: The European Parliament elections use proportional representation, which tends to favor smaller parties compared to first-past-the-post systems. 4. National politics: The performance of ID-affiliated parties in national elections across EU member states has been mixed, with some gains but also setbacks in different countries. 5. Voter turnout: European Parliament elections typically have lower turnout than national elections, which can sometimes benefit more ideologically driven parties with committed supporters. 6. Competition: Other political groups, particularly the center-right European People's Party (EPP) and the center-left Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D), have historically dominated the European Parliament and have well-established structures and support bases. 7. Political climate: Issues such as immigration, economic challenges, and debates about European integration could influence voter preferences, potentially benefiting the ID group. 8. Time until election: With the election still about a year away, there's significant time for political shifts and events that could impact voting patterns. Given these factors, while the ID group may gain seats in the 2024 elections, it seems unlikely that they will become the largest group in the European Parliament. The established mainstream parties still have significant support, and while right-wing populism has grown, it hasn't yet reached a level where it's likely to dominate the European Parliament. However, political landscapes can change rapidly, and unexpected events could shift voter preferences. Therefore, while unlikely, it's not impossible for the ID group to become the largest.

However, the French political landscape can be volatile, and the President can change the Prime Minister at any time. The current government faces challenges and protests, which could lead to a reshuffling. However, President Macron's party still holds a significant position, and it's more likely that any change would come from within the current coalition rather than a complete shift to an opposition party. (b) Regarding the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections: The Identity and Democracy (ID) group is a right-wing to far-right political group in the European Parliament. Currently, it's the fifth-largest group in the Parliament. For this part to resolve YES, ID would need to become the largest group after the 2024 elections. While right-wing and populist parties have been gaining ground in various European countries, it would be a significant shift for ID to become the largest group. The current largest groups (EPP, S&D) have traditionally held more seats and have broader appeal across multiple countries. However, political trends across Europe have been showing increased support for right-wing parties in several countries. The ongoing issues like immigration, economic challenges, and dissatisfaction with mainstream parties could potentially boost support for ID-affiliated parties. Considering both parts, there's a higher chance of (a) occurring than (b). The French political situation is more likely to change within a year than the ID group becoming the largest in the European Parliament. However, neither outcome is highly probable. Given these factors, I would estimate a moderate probability for this question resolving YES.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of M. Night Shyamalan's "Trap" (2024) receiving a CinemaScore of B or above, we need to consider several factors: 1. Recent track record: Looking at Shyamalan's recent films, we see a downward trend in CinemaScores: - "Split" (2016): B+ - "Glass" (2019): B - "Old" (2021): C+ - "Knock at the Cabin" (2023): C This trend suggests that audience reception of his recent works has been declining. 2. Shyamalan's reputation: He's known for his twist endings and unique storytelling style. While this has garnered him a dedicated fanbase, it has also led to mixed receptions for many of his films. 3. Genre and expectations: "Trap" is described as a psychological thriller. Shyamalan tends to perform better in this genre compared to his attempts at other genres. 4. Trailer reception: The question mentions that "Trap" has a great trailer. This could potentially build positive expectations among viewers, which might translate to a more favorable CinemaScore if the film meets or exceeds these expectations. 5. Unpredictability: Shyamalan's films are often polarizing, making audience reception hard to predict. His ability to surprise audiences can work both for and against him. 6. Time since last film: With "Knock at the Cabin" releasing in 2023, Shyamalan has had some time to potentially refine his approach based on recent feedback. Given these factors, I believe "Trap" has a chance to break the recent downward trend, but it's not highly likely. The great trailer and Shyamalan's experience in the psychological thriller genre work in its favor. However, the recent trend of lower scores and the general unpredictability of audience reception to his films suggest caution. Considering all these factors, I estimate there's a moderate chance that "Trap" will receive a CinemaScore of B or above, but it's less likely than not.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of this question resolving YES, we need to consider both conditions separately and then combine their probabilities. 1. "House of the Dragon" S2E8 rating >8.5 on IMDB: - Season 1 ratings ranged from 8.0 to 9.3, with several episodes likely above 8.5. - Season 2 ratings so far range from 6.1 to 9.6, showing more variability. - As the season finale, episode 8 is likely to be significant and potentially highly rated. - However, the requirement of >8.5 (not ≥8.5) makes this a slightly stricter condition. - Given the show's history and the importance of finales, I estimate a 60% chance of this condition being met. 2. M. Night Shyamalan's "Trap" receiving a CinemaScore of B or above: - Shyamalan's recent films have received CinemaScores ranging from C to B+. - This shows inconsistency in audience reception. - A score of B or above includes B, B+, and A-range scores. - Given Shyamalan's track record, achieving a B or above seems challenging but not impossible. - I estimate a 40% chance of this condition being met. To resolve YES, only one of these conditions needs to be met. Using the formula for the probability of at least one event occurring: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B) = 0.60 + 0.40 - (0.60 * 0.40) = 1 - (0.40 * 0.60) = 1 - 0.24 = 0.76.
